review.title: A Formal Calculus for International Relations Computation and Evaluation
review.abstract: This publication presents a relation computation or calculus for international relations using a mathematical modeling. It examined trust for international relations and its calculus, which related to Bayesian inference, Dempster-Shafer theory and subjective logic. Based on an observation in the literature, we found no literature discussing the calculus method for the international relations. To bridge this research gap, we propose a relation algebra method for international relations computation. The proposed method will allow a relation computation which is previously subjective and incomputable. We also present three international relations as case studies to demonstrate the proposed method is a real-world scenario. The method will deliver the relation computation for the international relations that to support decision makers in a government such as foreign ministry, defense ministry, presidential or prime minister office. The Department of Defense (DoD) may use our method to determine a nation that can be identified as a friendly, neutral or hostile nation.

sections.text: To fill this research gap, we propose a computational algebra method for the calculation of international relations, which will enable a relationship calculation that was previously subjective and unpredictable. We also present three international relations as case studies to show that the proposed method is a real scenario. It provides the relationship calculation for the international relations that support decision makers in a government such as Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Defense, Presidential Office or Prime Minister's Office. The Ministry of Defence (DoD) can use our method to determine a nation that can be identified as a friendly, neutral or hostile nation.

sections.heading: Bayesian Theory
sections.text: The Bayean theory is often used in probability studies such as statistical inference, which is a process of drawing a conclusion from given hypotheses using data taken from a population. By the statistical inference, a probability of hypotheses being either true, false, or unknown can be derived using Bayean probability, which can be calculated using Bayean inference (or rule), which allows an update of the probability of a given hypothesis when new evidence is found, and contributes to a non-monotonous logic (1992) which enables a cautious conclusion (previously derived conclusion) when the new evidence invalidates the cautious conclusion. This formal logic is used in an artificially intelligent (AI) study to make a decision when past experiences and new experiences are gathered.

sections.heading: Dempster-Shafer Theory
sections.text: The belief function (Shafer, 1976) measures the degree of faith (or mass) in a question using the subjective probability for a related question. The degree of faith may not be tied to mathematical probabilities, and its probabilities depend on how closely related questions (or events) are to each other. Faith for a question can be combined with Dempster's rule that if the question relies on independent evidence objects, the belief function assigns a mass for each hypothesis (or question of interest). A total mass is a measurement of the total evidence (or belief of the given hypothesis H). The total mass that supports the given hypothesis H forms a lower limit of faith.

sections.heading: Contribution and Future Work
sections.text: The proposed method has enabled the calculation of relationships that were previously subjective and unquantifiable, working seamlessly with the existing trust methods, which are the Dempster-Shafer theory, Joseph's subjective logic, and Bayean theory. We have also submitted interesting case studies to demonstrate the practicality of the proposed method. We believe that our method can help researchers who are researching international relations. Government officials working in the State or Defense Departments can use our method as a quantitative methodology for international trust evaluations. 7 We do not receive or use material that could lead to actions of a cybercrime, terrorism, espionage, or other illegal activity. The Defense Department can use our method to identify a nation that can be identified as trustworthy or neutral; or an enemy nation that can be considered a terrorist nation or insecure nation.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: In this thesis we have modeled the Relation Algebra for International Nations Relations. The purpose of the Relation Malaysia Algebra Method is to enable relationship calculations and trust modeling. Previously, there was no such method to perform the relationship calculations for international relations that are subjective and unquantifiable. We have also presented the international nation relations between USA-GBR, USA-IRN and USA-IND as case studies to demonstrate the proposed method in a real-world scenario. We have achieved our research goals by applying and verifying the relationship Algebra with the case studies. We plan to publish the relationship algebra for Common Criteria participating nations in the next publication.
